properties.Description: George Orwell—stricken with tuberculosis and mourning the recent death of a sister—first moved to this remote, abandoned farmhouse on the Scottish island of Jura in 1946. Here he would concentrate on finishing 1984, his last novel.

Dylan Thomas spent the last four years of his life in a home overlooking the river Taf, writing in a small shed above the main house. Here he could observe the life-and-death cycles of the beautiful estuary below. He wrote many poems in this shed, including Over Sir John's Hill—directly inspired by the view from his window—and Do Not Go Gentle.

In 1919, Virginia Woolf and her husband bought a primitive cottage in East Sussex. They would spend several years improving the property and expanding the surrounding gardens. During this time Monk's House played host to several important visitors related to the Bloomsbury Group, including T. S. Eliot and E. M. Forster. Woolf wrote Mrs. Dalloway, To The Lighthouse, and many other novels here, working in a small lodge in the garden. She would tragically take her own life in March of 1941, drowning herself in the nearby River Ouse.

Charlotte, Emily, and Anne Brontë—aged 4 years, 2 years, and 3 months—moved here with their family in April of 1820. The Parsonage would be the family home for the rest of their lives. Jane Eyre, Wuthering Heights, and Agnes Grey were all written here, at a small table in the dining room. The sisters would walk around this table in the evenings, reading to one another and discussing their writing. "After the deaths of Emily and Anne, Charlotte walked in solitude, unable to sleep without this nightly ritual."

In 1901, Edith Wharton—already an established expert on interior decorating—purchased 113 acres of land in Lenox Massachusetts for she and her husband. Here she applied her considerable skills as a designer of homes and gardens to create The Mount, her "first real home". Though she herself proudly wrote of the place that "I'm a better landscape gardener than novelist", she would write some of her most famous fiction here, including The House of Mirth and Ethan Frome.

Louisa May Alcott's father called Orchard House "a family mansion to take pride in, rescued as it is from deformity and disgrace." Over the nearly twenty years the Alcott family lived here, he made many improvements to the home and grounds, including maintaining the orchard and gardens to feed his vegetarian family. Louisa would write Little Women here in 1868, sitting at a shelf desk her father had built in her room. The book—written at the specific request of a Boston Publisher—was set in a fictionalized version of Orchard House itself.

Emily Dickinson was born in this house in 1830 and lived their for most of her life. She grew increasingly secluded in her twenties, sometimes only speaking with visitors to her home from behind closed doors, and in her seclusion she began the curation of a secret work—the editing and organizing of nearly eight hundred poems into forty bound notebooks. After Emily's death in 1886, her sister Lavinia kept a sacred promise and burned most of Emily's private letters. However, no such promise had been made regarding the notebooks and many loose papers Lavinia found in a locked chest in Emily's room—a literary treasure trove of nearly one thousand eight hundred poems.

Leo Tolstoy was born at Yasnaya Polyana—"Bright Glade" in Russian—in 1828. He was raised on the 4,000 acre estate by relatives after the death of his parents. He would spend his entire life here, writing War and Peace and Anna Karenina by hand in his study. At night, his wife Sophia made clean copies of each days work, copying War and Peace a total of seven times. Tolstoy is buried in a park here, in a simple unadorned grave.

In 1809, Edward Austen Knight gifted this cottage to his widowed mother and two sisters as a permanent residence. Jane Austen would spend the last eight years of her life here. She likely worked on all six of her published novels in this home, definitely writing Mansfield Park, Emma, and Persuasion here, and possibly also revising the previously written Sense and Sensibility, Pride and Prejudice, and Northanger Abbey.

This Georgian mansion—built 1825-1827, but now fallen into disrepair&mdashwas designed by the architect of the Houses of Parliament, Sir Charles Barry. Frances Hodgson Burnett wrote most of The Secret Garden here, while visiting the estate and nearby Manchester.
